00018 
00019 /*
00020  * ==============================================================================
00021  *
00022  *                   FCVBBD Interface Package
00023  * 
00024  * The FCVBBD Interface Package is a package of C functions which,
00025  * together with the FCVODE Interface Package, support the use of the
00026  * CVODE solver (parallel MPI version) with the CVBBDPRE preconditioner module,
00027  * for the solution of ODE systems in a mixed Fortran/C setting.  The
00028  * combination of CVODE and CVBBDPRE solves systems dy/dt = f(t,y) with
00029  * the SPGMR (scaled preconditioned GMRES), SPTFQMR (scaled preconditioned TFQMR),
00030  * or SPBCG (scaled preconditioned Bi-CGSTAB) method for the linear systems that
00031  * arise, and with a preconditioner that is block-diagonal with banded blocks.
00032  * While CVODE and CVBBDPRE are written in C, it is assumed here that the user's
00033  * calling program and user-supplied problem-defining routines are written in
00034  * Fortran.
00035  * 
00036  * The user-callable functions in this package, with the corresponding
00037  * CVODE and CVBBDPRE functions, are as follows: 
00038  *   FCVBBDININT   interfaces to CVBBDPrecAlloc
00039  *   FCVBBDSPTFQMR interfaces to CVBBDSptfqmr
00040  *   FCVBBDSPBCG   interfaces to CVBBDSpbcg
00041  *   FCVBBDPSGMR   interfaces to CVBBDSpgmr
00042  *   FCVBBDREINIT  interfaces to CVBBDPrecReInit
00043  *   FCVBBDOPT     accesses optional outputs
00044  *   FCVBBDFREE    interfaces to CVBBDPrecFree
00045  * 
00046  * In addition to the Fortran right-hand side function FCVFUN, the
00047  * user-supplied functions used by this package, are listed below,
00048  * each with the corresponding interface function which calls it (and its
00049  * type within CVBBDPRE or CVODE):
00050  *   FCVLOCFN  is called by the interface function FCVgloc of type CVLocalFn
00051  *   FCVCOMMF  is called by the interface function FCVcfn of type CVCommFn
00052  *   FCVJTIMES (optional) is called by the interface function FCVJtimes of 
00053  *             type CVSpilsJtimesFn
00054  * (The names of all user-supplied routines here are fixed, in order to
00055  * maximize portability for the resulting mixed-language program.)
00056  * 
00057  * Important note on portability.
00058  * In this package, the names of the interface functions, and the names of
00059  * the Fortran user routines called by them, appear as dummy names
00060  * which are mapped to actual values by a series of definitions in the
00061  * header file fcvbbd.h.
00062  * 
00063  * ==============================================================================
00064  * 
00065  *               Usage of the FCVODE/FCVBBD Interface Packages
00066  * 
00067  * The usage of the combined interface packages FCVODE and FCVBBD requires
00068  * calls to seven to twelve interface functions, and three or four user-supplied
00069  * routines which define the problem to be solved and indirectly define
00070  * the preconditioner.  These function calls and user routines are
00071  * summarized separately below.
00072  * 
00073  * Some details are omitted, and the user is referred to the CVODE user document 
00074  * for more complete information.
00075  * 
00076  * (1) User-supplied right-hand side routine: FCVFUN
00077  * The user must in all cases supply the following Fortran routine
00078  *       SUBROUTINE FCVFUN (T, Y, YDOT, IPAR, RPAR, IER)
00079  *       DIMENSION Y(*), YDOT(*), IPAR(*), RPAR(*)
00080  * It must set the YDOT array to f(t,y), the right-hand side of the ODE
00081  * system, as function of T = t and the array Y = y.  Here Y and YDOT
00082  * are distributed vectors.
00083  * 
00084  * (2) User-supplied routines to define preconditoner: FCVLOCFN and FCVCOMMF
00085  * 
00086  * The routines in the CVBBDPRE module provide a preconditioner matrix
00087  * for CVODE that is block-diagonal with banded blocks.  The blocking
00088  * corresponds to the distribution of the dependent variable vector y
00089  * among the processors.  Each preconditioner block is generated from the
00090  * Jacobian of the local part (on the current processor) of a given
00091  * function g(t,y) approximating f(t,y).  The blocks are generated by a
00092  * difference quotient scheme on each processor independently, utilizing
00093  * an assumed banded structure with given half-bandwidths.  A separate
00094  * pair of half-bandwidths defines the band matrix retained.
00095  * 
00096  * (2.1) Local approximate function FCVLOCFN.
00097  * The user must supply a subroutine of the form
00098  *       SUBROUTINE FCVLOCFN (NLOC, T, YLOC, GLOC, IPAR, RPAR, IER)
00099  *       DIMENSION YLOC(*), GLOC(*), IPAR(*), RPAR(*)
00100  * to compute the function g(t,y) which approximates the right-hand side
00101  * function f(t,y).  This function is to be computed locally, i.e. without 
00102  * interprocess communication.  (The case where g is mathematically
00103  * identical to f is allowed.)  It takes as input the local vector length
00104  * NLOC, the independent variable value T = t, and the local realtype
00105  * dependent variable array YLOC.  It is to compute the local part of
00106  * g(t,y) and store this in the realtype array GLOC.
00107  * On return, set IER = 0 if successful, IER > 0 if a recoverable error occurred,
00108  * and IER < 0 if an unrecoverable error ocurred.
00109  * 
00110  * (2.2) Communication function FCVCOMMF.
00111  * The user must also supply a subroutine of the form
00112  *       SUBROUTINE FCVCOMMF (NLOC, T, YLOC, IPAR, RPAR, IER)
00113  *       DIMENSION YLOC(*), IPAR(*), RPAR(*)
00114  * which is to perform all interprocess communication necessary to
00115  * evaluate the approximate right-hand side function g described above.
00116  * This function takes as input the local vector length NLOC, the
00117  * independent variable value T = t, and the local real dependent
00118  * variable array YLOC.  It is expected to save communicated data in 
00119  * work space defined by the user, and made available to CVLOCFN.
00120  * Each call to the FCVCOMMF is preceded by a call to FCVFUN with the same
00121  * (t,y) arguments.  Thus FCVCOMMF can omit any communications done by 
00122  * FCVFUN if relevant to the evaluation of g.
00123  * On return, set IER = 0 if successful, IER > 0 if a recoverable error occurred,
00124  * and IER < 0 if an unrecoverable error ocurred.
00125  * 
00126  * (3) Optional user-supplied Jacobian-vector product routine: FCVJTIMES
00127  * As an option, the user may supply a routine that computes the product
00128  * of the system Jacobian J = df/dy and a given vector v.  If supplied, it
00129  * must have the following form:
00130  *       SUBROUTINE FCVJTIMES (V, FJV, T, Y, FY, EWT, IPAR, RPAR, WORK, IER)
00131  *       DIMENSION V(*), FJV(*), Y(*), FY(*), EWT(*), IPAR(*), RPAR(*), WORK(*)
00132  * Typically this routine will use only NEQ, T, Y, V, and FJV.  It must
00133  * compute the product vector Jv, where the vector v is stored in V, and store
00134  * the product in FJV.  On return, set IER = 0 if FCVJTIMES was successful,
00135  * and nonzero otherwise.
00136  * 
00137  * (4) Initialization:  FNVINITP, FCVMALLOC, FCVBBDINIT.
00138  * 
00139  * (4.1) To initialize the parallel vector specification, the user must make 
00140  * the following call:
00141  *        CALL FNVINITP (NLOCAL, NGLOBAL, IER)
00142  * The arguments are:
00143  * NLOCAL  = local size of vectors on this processor
00144  * NGLOBAL = the system size, and the global size of vectors (the sum 
00145  *           of all values of NLOCAL)
00146  * IER     = return completion flag. Values are 0 = success, -1 = failure.
00147  * 
00148  * Note: If MPI was initialized by the user, the communicator must be
00149  * set to MPI_COMM_WORLD.  If not, this routine initializes MPI and sets
00150  * the communicator equal to MPI_COMM_WORLD.
00151  * 
00152  * (4.2) To set various problem and solution parameters and allocate
00153  * internal memory for CVODE, make the following call:
00154  *       CALL FCVMALLOC(T0, Y0, METH, ITMETH, IATOL, RTOL, ATOL,
00155  *      1               IOUT, ROUT, IPAR, RPAR, IER)
00156  * The arguments are:
00157  * T0     = initial value of t
00158  * Y0     = array of initial conditions
00159  * METH   = basic integration method: 1 = Adams (nonstiff), 2 = BDF (stiff)
00160  * ITMETH = nonlinear iteration method: 1 = functional iteration, 2 = Newton iter.
00161  * IATOL  = type for absolute tolerance ATOL: 1 = scalar, 2 = array
00162  * RTOL   = relative tolerance (scalar)
00163  * ATOL   = absolute tolerance (scalar or array)
00164  * IOUT   = array of length 21 for integer optional outputs
00165  *          (declare as INTEGER*4 or INTEGER*8 according to C type long int)
00166  * ROUT   = array of length 6 for real optional outputs
00167  * IPAR   = array with user integer data
00168  *          (declare as INTEGER*4 or INTEGER*8 according to C type long int)
00169  * RPAR   = array with user real data
00170  * IER    = return completion flag.  Values are 0 = success, and -1 = failure.
00171  *          See printed message for details in case of failure.
00172  * 
00173  * (4.3) To allocate memory and initialize data associated with the CVBBDPRE
00174  * preconditioner, make the following call:
00175  *       CALL FCVBBDINIT(NLOCAL, MUDQ, MLDQ, MU, ML, DQRELY, IER)
00176  * 
00177  * The arguments are:
00178  * NLOCAL    = local size of vectors on this processor
00179  * MUDQ,MLDQ = upper and lower half-bandwidths to be used in the computation
00180  *             of the local Jacobian blocks by difference quotients.
00181  *             These may be smaller than the true half-bandwidths of the
00182  *             Jacobian of the local block of g, when smaller values may
00183  *             provide greater efficiency.
00184  * MU, ML    = upper and lower half-bandwidths of the band matrix that 
00185  *             is retained as an approximation of the local Jacobian block.
00186  *             These may be smaller than MUDQ and MLDQ.
00187  * DQRELY    = relative increment factor in y for difference quotients
00188  *             (optional). 0.0 indicates the default, sqrt(unit roundoff).
00189  * IER       = return completion flag: IER=0: success, IER<0: an error occurred
00190  *
00191  * (4.4A) To specify the SPGMR linear system solver and use it with the CVBBDPRE
00192  * preconditioner, make the following call:
00193  *       CALL FCVBBDSPGMR(IPRETYPE, IGSTYPE, MAXL, DELT, IER)
00194  * The arguments are:
00195  * IPRETYPE  = preconditioner type: 
00196  *             0 = none
00197  *             1 = left only
00198  *             2 = right only
00199  *             3 = both sides.
00200  * IGSTYPE   = Gram-schmidt process type: 1 = modified G-S, 1 = classical G-S.
00201  * MAXL      = maximum Krylov subspace dimension; 0 indicates default.
00202  * DELT      = linear convergence tolerance factor; 0.0 indicates default.
00203  * IER       = return completion flag: IER=0: success, IER<0: an error occurred
00204  *
00205  * (4.4B) To specify the SPBCG linear system solver and use it with the CVBBDPRE
00206  * preconditioner, make the following call:
00207  *       CALL FCVBBDSPBCG(IPRETYPE, MAXL, DELT, IER)
00208  * The arguments are:
00209  * IPRETYPE  = preconditioner type: 
00210  *             0 = none
00211  *             1 = left only
00212  *             2 = right only
00213  *             3 = both sides.
00214  * MAXL      = maximum Krylov subspace dimension; 0 indicates default.
00215  * DELT      = linear convergence tolerance factor; 0.0 indicates default.
00216  * IER       = return completion flag: IER=0: success, IER<0: an error occurred
00217  *
00218  * (4.4C) To specify the SPTFQMR linear system solver and use it with the CVBBDPRE
00219  * preconditioner, make the following call:
00220  *       CALL FCVBBDSPTFQMR(IPRETYPE, MAXL, DELT, IER)
00221  * The arguments are:
00222  * IPRETYPE  = preconditioner type: 
00223  *             0 = none
00224  *             1 = left only
00225  *             2 = right only
00226  *             3 = both sides.
00227  * MAXL      = maximum Krylov subspace dimension; 0 indicates default.
00228  * DELT      = linear convergence tolerance factor; 0.0 indicates default.
00229  * IER       = return completion flag: IER=0: success, IER<0: an error occurred
00230  *
00231  * (4.5) To specify whether the Krylov linear solver (GMRES, Bi-CGSTAB, or TFQMR)
00232  * should use the supplied FCVJTIMES or the internal finite difference approximation, 
00233  * make the call
00234  *        CALL FCVSPILSSETJAC(FLAG, IER)
00235  * where FLAG=0 for finite differences approximation or
00236  *       FLAG=1 to use the supplied routine FCVJTIMES
00237  * 
00238  * (5) Re-initialization: FCVREINIT, FCVBBDREINIT
00239  * If a sequence of problems of the same size is being solved using the SPGMR, SPBCG,
00240  * SPTFQMR linear solver in combination with the CVBBDPRE preconditioner, then the
00241  * CVODE package can be reinitialized for the second and subsequent problems
00242  * so as to avoid further memory allocation.  First, in place of the call
00243  * to FCVMALLOC, make the following call:
00244  *       CALL FCVREINIT(T0, Y0, IATOL, RTOL, ATOL, IER)
00245  * The arguments have the same names and meanings as those of FCVMALLOC, except
00246  * that METH and ITMETH have been omitted from the argument list (being unchanged
00247  * for the new problem).  FCVREINIT performs the same initializations as
00248  * FCVMALLOC, but does no memory allocation, using instead the existing
00249  * internal memory created by the previous FCVMALLOC call.
00250  * Following the call to FCVREINIT, a call to FCVBBDINIT may or may not be needed.
00251  * If the input arguments are the same, no FCVBBDINIT call is needed.
00252  * If there is a change in input arguments, then make the call
00253  *      CALL FCVBBDREINIT(NLOCAL, MUDQ, MLDQ, DQRELY, IER)
00254  * This reinitializes the SP* linear solver, but without reallocating its memory.
00255  * The arguments of the have the same names and meanings as FCVBBDINIT.  
00256  * If the value of MU or ML is being changed, then a call to FCVBBDINIT must
00257  * be made.  If there is a change in any of the linear solver arguments, then
00258  * a call to FCVBBDSPGMR, FCVBBDSPBCG, or FCVBBDSPTFQMR must also be made;
00259  * in this case the linear solver memory is reallocated. 
00260  * 
00261  * (6) The integrator: FCVODE
00262  * Carrying out the integration is accomplished by making calls as follows:
00263  *       CALL FCVODE (TOUT, T, Y, ITASK, IER)
00264  * The arguments are:
00265  * TOUT  = next value of t at which a solution is desired (input)
00266  * T     = value of t reached by the solver on output
00267  * Y     = array containing the computed solution on output
00268  * ITASK = task indicator: 
00269  *         1 = normal mode (overshoot TOUT and interpolate)
00270  *         2 = one-step mode (return after each internal step taken)
00271  *         3 = normal mode with TSTOP check
00272  *         4 = one-step mode with TSTOP check
00273  * IER   = completion flag: 0 = success, 1 = TSTOP return, 2 = root return,
00274  *         negative values are various failure modes (see CVODE User Guide).
00275  * The current values of the optional outputs are available in IOUT and ROUT.
00276  * 
00277  * (7) Optional outputs: FCVBBDOPT
00278  * Optional outputs specific to the SP* solver are LRW, LIW, LFLG, NFELS, NJTV,
00279  * NPE, NPS, NLI, NCFL, stored in IOUT(13)...IOUT(21).
00280  * To obtain the optional outputs associated with the CVBBDPRE module, make
00281  * the following call:
00282  *       CALL FCVBBDOPT (LENRWBBD, LENIWBBD, NGEBBD)
00283  * The arguments returned are:
00284  * LENRWBBD = length of real preconditioner work space, in realtype words.
00285  *            This size is local to the current processor.
00286  * LENIWBBD = length of integer preconditioner work space, in integer words.
00287  *            This size is local to the current processor.
00288  * NGEBBD   = number of g(t,y) evaluations (calls to CVLOCFN) so far.
00289  * 
00290  * (8) Computing solution derivatives: FCVDKY
00291  * To obtain a derivative of the solution (optionally), of order up to
00292  * the current method order, make the following call:
00293  *       CALL FCVDKY (T, K, DKY)
00294  * The arguments are:
00295  * T   = value of t at which solution derivative is desired
00296  * K   = derivative order (0 .le. K .le. QU)
00297  * DKY = array containing computed K-th derivative of y on return
00298  * 
00299  * (9) Memory freeing: FCVBBDFREE and FCVFREE
00300  *   To the free the internal memory created by the calls to FNVINITP,
00301  * FCVMALLOC, and FCVBBDINIT, make the following calls, in this order:
00302  *       CALL FCVBBDFREE
00303  *       CALL FCVFREE
00304  *
00305  * ==============================================================================
00306  */
00307

00410 void FCV_BBDINIT(long int *Nloc, long int *mudq, long int *mldq, 
00411                  long int *mu, long int *ml, realtype* dqrely, int *ier);
00412 void FCV_BBDSPTFQMR(int *pretype, int *maxl, realtype *delt, int *ier);
